unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Confidence Level and $1$-sided Significance Testing
question_text:
A one sample $t$-test for was used to conduct a test of the null hypotheses:
$${ H }_{ 0 }:\mu =28$$ $${ H }_{ a }:\mu <28$$
The $p$-value was $0.006$. A confidence interval for *$\mu$ * is to be constructed.
Of the following, which is the largest level of confidence for which the confidence interval will NOT contain $28$?
solution:
Since we do not want the confidence interval to contain $28$, this indicates we want to reject the null hypotheses.

Notice that in this case, the alternative hypothesis is one-sided, whereas the confidence interval measures a $2$-sided test. The easiest way to approach this is to make the alternative two-sided by doubling the $p$-value. Our new $p$-value will be $0.012$.

For each one of the confidence levels, create the significance level that corresponds to the confidence level. Then, see if you would reject or fail to reject the null hypotheses using the $p$-value and significance level.

For a $95\%$ confidence level, the significance level is $5\%$. $0.012 < 0.05$; therefore we reject the null hypotheses.

For a $96\%$ confidence level, the significance level is $4\%$. $0.012 < 0.04$; therefore, we reject the null hypotheses.

For a $97\%$ confidence level, the significance level is $3\%$. $0.012 < 0.03$; therefore, we reject the null hypotheses.

For a $98\%$ confidence level, the significance level is $2\%$. $0.012< 0.02$; therefore, we reject the null hypotheses.

For a $99\%$ confidence level, the significance level is $1\%$. $0.012 > 0.01$; therefore, we fail to reject the null hypotheses.

The largest confidence interval that will not contain $28$ is $98\%$.
